            SUPPORT PROGRAM,TF039616-ZAMBIA - ENVIRONMENT SUPPORT PROJECT,TF039865-ZAMBIA - ENVIRONMENT SUPPORT PROGRAM,TF040608-ZAMBIA - ENVIRONMENTAL SUPPORT PROGRAM,TF040864-ZAMBIA: ENVIRONMENTAL SUPPORT PROGRAM

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Environmental
            Support Program for Zambia were as follows: the outcome was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, the Bank and
            borrower performance were both unsatisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the complexity of design, number of
            components and implementing agencies, and dependency of key
            project activities on other donors must be minimized to
            reduce the implementation risks associated with these
            project features. Thorough preparation of the project,
            particularly clarification of institutional issues and
            implementation arrangements, is crucial for satisfactory
            launch of implementation. In the Africa Region, use of the
            Readiness for Implementation filter developed by AFTQK to
            check if the project is adequately prepared. Fashionable but
            unproven trends in project design, e.g., avoidance of
            Project Management Unit (PMUs) in countries with
            insufficient implementation capacity, or cookie-cutter
            approach using the same project design in different country
            circumstances, should be resisted. Summary suspension of
            project activities and early closure of non-performing
            projects is desirable from the perspective of portfolio
            management, freeing of under-utilized funds and forging more
            effective dialogue with the government. For projects with
            low government ownership and deteriorating responsiveness,
            early intervention by the sector and country management is
            necessary to complement the supervision efforts of the task
            team so the project can be revived and brought on track
            early. In the case of clearly unrealistic and unachievable
            project objectives, these must be revised downward otherwise
            no improvement in project performance will be sufficient to
            earn the project satisfactory ratings.
